Award.AwardTitle: Mountain top mining effects on watershed hydrology and biogeochemistry: Learning from manipulation of the critical zone
Award.AbstractNarration:
The watershed landscape in Central Appalachia is rapidly changing as a result of mountain top mining of coal with valley fill (MTMVF). During MTMVF operations, mountain ridges are removed with explosives to expose seams of coal too shallow to require underground mining. The waste rocks generated from these ridges are then deposited in adjacent stream valleys, filling the valleys beneath tens to hundreds of meters of this overburden. The landscapes left behind are dramatically altered and present both a significant challenge and opportunity to explore how the human restructuring of a watershed alters the timing and chemistry of stream flows. Through comparative analyses of mined and unmined watersheds, this project will provide much needed knowledge about how water availability, water quality, and flood risks are being altered by MTMVF.

Little prior knowledge exists for predicting hydrologic response to this extreme landscape disturbance that penetrates hundreds of meters into bedrock and leaves behind a reconfigured topography overlying a reorganized subsurface. MTMVF must drastically alter watershed hydrology and solute transport dynamics. Yet basic hydrologic theory and experimental manipulations of vegetation and surficial soils are insufficient to predict how MTMVF will change the magnitude and timing of water and solute transport in watersheds. This project will combine high resolution terrain analyses, intensive field measurement campaigns, and cutting edge modeling tools to examine and predict how hydro-biogeochemical responses to precipitation differ between mined and unmined landscapes from headwater to river basin scales. This research will also provide insight into how land surface and subsurface structures interact to influence hydrological and geochemical dynamics, improving our understanding of watershed hydrology in both natural and disturbed landscapes.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project assessed the impact of mountaintop removal coal mining with valley fills (MTMVF) on the topography, hydrology and vegetation of Appalachian watersheds and on the hydrology, chemistry and biodiversity of Appalachian rivers. Researchers used remote sensing approaches to determine that MTMVF has converted 2300 square miles of Appalachian forests into abandoned, reclaimed and active surface coal mines and valley fills. They discovered that decades of MTMVF activities have resulted in a detectable flattening of the topography and an increase in the mean elevation of southern West Virginia, with the filling of 1544 individual stream valleys offsetting the removal of mountain ridges. They determined that in the aggregate, these valley fills contain ~1.5 cubic miles of unconsolidated rock. Detailed comparisons between mined and unmined paired catchments revealed that in mined catchments, less rainfall is routed directly into stream channels, resulting in higher sustained baseflows and lower peak flows. Water stored in MTMVF fill materials accumulates the products of chemical weathering, and the resulting salt-laden waters export ~20 tons of rock derived salts from every acre of mined land each year. These salts increase the conductivity and trace contaminant concentrations of rivers throughout the region and, based on eDNA surveys, are associated with the loss of sensitive microbial, algal, macroinvertebrate and fish taxa from mining-impacted streams. Not all of these contaminants remain in rivers, predatory spiders living alongside these mining-impacted streams were found to have among the highest body burdens of selenium (a rock derived contaminant) in their tissues as a result of feeding on emergent aquatic insects, posing a particular toxicity risk for forest birds.

This project supported the research of three postdoctoral associates, three graduate students and four undergraduate independent research projects. The results of this project have been disseminated through four published manuscripts (with seven more in preparation), three online data applications that allow users to explore indidual datasets, and more than 30 conference presentations and invited lectures. Papers published from this research to date have been covered by more than 40 separate news outlets, indicating high public interest in the findings from this research effort.
